reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Strengthening of resilience capacities through comprehensive emergency WASH interventions in the most vulnerable areas of the Gaza Strip

description.narrative: This intervention is an immediate response to ensure that girls, boys, women, men, elderly with and without disabilities have sufficient access to save-living and adequate services. The intervention envisages providing the most vulnerable families sufficient means to respond to their WASH related needs, exacerbated in summer. Specifically, the action aims at improving access to domestic water supply and storage for families through intervention at households (HHs), wastewater services at HHs level, and raising hygiene awareness. The action will also intervene at community level to increase the water supply. Further, the project addresses the significant gap in humanitarian needs, especially targeting women heads of HHs and war widows. Implemented activities will take into account different and specific needs of women and girls. Provision of improved access to safe water through better water supply system will reflect the different uses of water and the impact this will have on family health. The hard component activities set will be provided at two levels (households and community), and will be complemented by hygiene awareness sessions, to ensure not just the sustainability of the project, but also, the logic of the intervention. Specifically the action will intervene at HHs’ level through construction of HH wastewater connections, and HH domestic water connections, provision and installation of safe domestic water storage units and adequate hygienic services, and at community level through rehabilitation/ construction of domestic water supply systems. 295 HHs, located in Al Mughraqa, Al Bureij and Al Nussirat localities (9 areas/neighborhoods), will benefit from the action. The proposed action will be implemented jointly by GVC and Rural Women Development Society (RWDS). These two organizations have a longstanding experience in collaborating together, as shown by the recent joint implementation of WASH emergency projects (Humanitarian response to improve access to basic sanitation and hygienic services for the most vulnerable girls, boys, women and men in the Gaza Strip, UNICEF-funded, 2017 Humanitarian response to improve the basic WASH conditions of the most vulnerable women, men, girls and boys in the Gaza Strip, UNICEF-funded, 2016).Coordination with WASH Cluster and its members, as well as communication with line municipalities, have been carried out during the design of this proposal. The action responds to the issues and needs raised by the PWA, CMWU and the line municipalities, specifically the criticality of the water and wastewater infrastructure conditions currently prevailing in the Gaza Strip and their inability to meet the needs, because of the government’s limited resources. In particular, the intervention related to the wastewater connections, will have significant positive impacts on the community environment and, therefore, on the health of the population.
